name: TransOcean: The Shipping Company
description: TransOcean – The Shipping Company is your ticket to the world of gigantic ships and transnational transport empires. Build a mighty fleet of modern merchant ships and conquer the seven seas.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows Vista/7/8 Processor: Dual Core 2 GHz (AMD or Intel) Memory: 4 GB RAM Graphics: Nvidia Geforce 7600 Series/ATI Radeon X1600 or better (min. 256 MB VRAM) DirectX: Version 9.0 Storage: 5 GB available space Sound Card: n/a
recommended_requirements: OS: Windows Vista/7/8 Processor: Dual Core 2,66 GHz (AMD or Intel) Memory: 4 GB RAM Graphics: ATI 4800 Series or comparable with 512 MB VRAM DirectX: Version 9.0 Storage: 5 GB available space Sound Card: n/a

reviews.review_text: I am not much of a game player, but have always been interested in the shipping business and business simulation. I was pleasantly surprised at how much I enjoyed playing this game. Some people will enjoy the docking of the vessels in the various harbors. As you gain experience you will be able to get to and from the dock faster. Some ports are extremely easy (Lisbon), and others, quite challenging (get one of the larger boats in and out of Vancouver). So people looking for a game that builds your skills handling various ships you will likely enjoy this.  There may be some small issues with the underlying rules. For example, was surprised I could pickup cargo from NY for Havana. Suspect that isn't a realistic route.--more likely such goods travel to an intermediate port first (like Halifax). Also, not totally sure the rules follow the Jones Act. But one can really spend time figuring out how to keep the vessels as loaded as possible, and efficiently moving the most TEUs for the most money. I didn't like it when my ships had less than 50% of the capacity in use at any one time. I found this more challenging then moving the boats around, and therefore I would sometimes just let the game dock the ship to save time even though it negatively affected my reputation.  Again, not a gamer, but surprised how much time I have spent playing and enjoying this game. If you like simulations, you'll probably find this entertaining, if not informative.

Well, after 13 hours of playing, I find it to be a very relaxing game.... As you get bigger ships, the ports seem to be alittle harder to get into... Game play itself is easy, the mini docking and undocking game makes it even more enteresting as you get to 'drive' the ships to there docking and undocking points... I DO enjoy the game and hope to see some little inmprovements in the future.... OTHERWISE.... GREAT GAME for ME.... Nice addition to MY library of SIMS....

I rarely buy games this expensive and at full price, but something urged me to get this after the first major update of bug fixes was released. There seems to be a wealth of official and unofficial game remakes recently and I definately feel we are encountering another golden age of PC gaming. This game is unofficially similar to the old DOS game 'Ports of Call'. Even though I did find the storyline a bit weak, and the gameplay slightly tedious towards the end I still really enjoyed this game which I completed in under 20 hours in Normal mode. I may well attempt the game at hard level or try playing it with an erection at some point. I am hoping that perhaps add ons or a follow up game will be released to improve the game, but if you have fond memories of POC I am sure you will enjoy this.

The idea of game is not bad, but requires additional motivation to the player for spending more time and reaches some targets. It starts boring to move the vessels in/out of ports many times, while the idea is a managing of Shipping Company. With a fleet size more than 100 ships the gameplay turns to a long-long row of mouth clicks. The player has to spend several hours to complete on month of game time. Another big issue, what to do with money? My account grows to 10 billion and I have no idea where to invest.  Hoping the Developers will read the comments of fans and apply the improvements to gaming process.

Well, it certainly is fun to play. That said, what you're buying isn't a business simulation with ships, but rather a 'send ship from a to b to c'.  If you want something where your actions have direct consequences on global markets or you want to mercilessly drive your competition out of business, play the Partrician/Port Royale series, or get Ocean Trader, it's ancient, but an actual simulation.  TransOcean doesn't let you automate anything, everything is based upon one time contracts, you have to micromanage every sincle ship, which in the beginning makes you fast-forward a lot and later, with several ships, stops the game everytime a ship docks at a port. If a shipping company would actually work like this, they'd be broker faster than you can say 'Panamax'.  Still, for some reason, I haven't been able to pull myself away from it. It's not great, but it is enjoyable.

everything was fine with the game the two things that killed it for me was the poor map view and boat graphics, just look like thin cigarettes moving around & the manual docking mode is sooooo incredibility tedious, unrealistic, rudimentary and boring. They even have the &%$#! to force you to dock the biggest and hardest boats for a story line mission! I hate it. Otherwise pretty fun game.

It's a solid thing-management game. The progress is satisfying, the trade contracts you get offered are just random enough that you have to think about which ones to get each time rather than mindlessly repeating a decision you arrived at much earlier (looking at you, Master of Orion 2 and Holy Potatoes), and the game automatically pauses in most of the places where I'd want it to.  Its greatest flaw is that the load times for the ship-parking minigame are so incredibly long I stopped bothering with it entirely fairly quickly.

This is not a simple management game, you actualy have to think about your routes, your ships, and the upgrades your gonna use, not to mention balance your income, since int eh the campagine 20% of your quarterly statement goes to the investor, which makes it interesting and not untainable.  the graphics are great, and for those that liek to skim out of haven to pay for a tug boat that auto-parks your ships, you can drive them your self, no port is so small for a ship so big to be parked, i managed to get a class 4 ship into a tiny port, though it took like 15mins, and that was cause i was curious to see if i could.  at the start, focus on the main ports to get multi shipments tot he same place and if you can also stops at ports inbetween, this allows you to gain tiny amounts of $$$ to get through to your second ship, after that you start to delve into a constant state of awerness of whats going on, though if you dont focus on upgrades (which i didn't) it can lead to fires, busted by the customs officers, and a few other nice little things that pop up time to time, priates will steal your ship and demand all your $$$ still have yet to find out how to counter them.  other then that this game is pretty good, though a few UI issues noticed that would help streamline the game a bit but other then that its pretty good.  8/10

Well there are some good gaming hours hidden in this game. If you miss Ports of Call from the good ol' days this is your thing. I had though expected a bit more of an update, with varieties to shipping. It's more than containers :)

So.  Terrible graphics in the harbor menu, poorly optimized (doesn't look good and slogs down to 20 fps) and horrible floaty controls. And if you don't want to do the pointless docking minigame every time one of your ships enters a harbour you have to pay some of your revenue. And you want to skip it because it is completely unnecessary.   The Tutorial is alright, though the boss lady takes lots of your revenue all the time, and hands you contracts that you simply can not fulfill in time because you can't afford the necessary ships yet.  Probably I'm doing something wrong but playing on easy that seemed a bit unfair that I would've needed to buy ships that cost 60 million when I only just could afford a ship that cost 20.  And then there are these long-time contracts. They seem like they're supposed to bring in a slow but steady stream of revenue, but why can't I just simply automate my ships to do those for me?  Overall a bit meh.
This game is great   lots to love about this game!!!  Its worth the time and money you will get hours of enjoyment!!!

Recommended overall if on sale, with some caveats.  I liked this game a great deal overall, despite the criticism I'm about to give it. It's been good value and good fun for me. Read on to see if it's for you.  This is a Tycoon game, not at all an accurate ship simulator. It's really more logistics oriented, and the financial aspects are weak. The simplistic mini-game of docking ships helps break the tedium, especially early on, but itself becomes tedious, particularly due to the lengthy loading times. I had no difficulties with the mini-game and I am decidedly not a twitch fast reflexes gamer. That said, casual or older gamers might not like the ship docking mini-game; fortunately it can mostly be skipped at the cost of some revenue. As the game progresses you'll likely be skipping it more and more.  I'd like to say it accurately depicts running a shipping company, but it really doesn't. The financial side of the game is incredibly weak and simplistic, with poor tools (no concept of a balance sheet or even a proper income statement, and some very strange criteria for a successful quarter. (e.g. there's an effort to calculate return on investment, but little concept of the passage of time, so back-loaded heavy ship purchases make your quarter 'unsuccessful' and you lose reputation.)  That said, the logistics (while simplistic compared to a genuine shipping company) are a nice thing, and piecing together company contracts and profitable semi-sustainable routes can be enjoyable for those who like that kind of thing.  Random events can be pretty irritating with wildly disproportionate penalties. More frequent cargo inspections with lower penalties would make more sense from a gaming perspective; as it is, the user is just tempted to reload when a potentially company-destroying penalty is applied randomly every couple of hours.  A couple of major downsides: some have reported major bugs, particularly in late game. While I've not yet encountered game-destroying bugs, I have encountered extreme slowdowns in the interface later in the game, especially with several ships in port. These lead me to suspect the coding to handle shipping consignments is at best weak and poorly optimized.  The final negative point is this, and why I cannot recommend paying full price. It's a quite good game for the first little bit, but the endgame feels very rough and unfinished. The tools to manage a large group of ships (50+) are quite poor, and the developers have indicated they are focusing all efforts on a version 2. At this point the game is more-or-less abandoned. This doesn't mean it's not worth buying; it does mean I don't believe its worth paying full price even if you love tycoon/financial/business games.  TL;DR: Good if on sale and you like tycoon/financial games. Seems rough and unfinished late in the game. Very enjoyable for what it is.

Pros - Great economy system - Impressive amounts of ships - Great Casual game if you don't want to pay much attentio to what you're doing, and can be an amazing in-depth game if you want to plan out every job with how much the fuel costs and maintenance compared to the payout - Even has a feature of taking illegal jobs which pay much better, but there is always the off chance that you're boat is checked by customs (I have yet to have been caught) - I love how hard you have to work to get to the next level of ships; to be able to sail the next biggest ship is just so gripping - I have yet to find a bug  Cons - Multiplayer is pretty much useless, the only thing it does is change the price of gas based on who goes to what ports, which creates a multitude of useless notifications on the side that I would forfit the feature just to get rid of - The docking system gets very boring and time-consuming. If you just want to play it as a econ sim then you can skip it for a very small fee - Reputation system is a useless addition - Can be grindy  Conclusion (tl;dr) A truely excellent economic simulation game, may be boring to those not interested in simulation games (if you found rct and the older simcities compelling, you will like this game) 8.5/10

I've only played about 10 hours, but so far I like this game. Just a few things for TO2 or if they are still fixing this game:  Zooming in on the Contract List menu map would be helpful. Leave the zoom level where I set it on every map. The world map scrolls with the mouse wheel when the Fuel Price list is open, it gets really annoying. It would be cool to be able to see the status of repair for ships in the List of Ships menu, maybe with a mouseover. Have the cities highlight on the World Map when you mouse over their names in the Fuel List.  Other than that, I plan to keep playing. Thanks for a fun game!
I love tycoon simulator type games and this one was perfect. Really fun and worth it
39h and still very addicted
love this game. the best part i have seen in this game so far is the challenge to get back your company.

TransOcean has got to be the best shipping game I've playrd yet.It has different types of cargo so you don't get tierd of hualing the same thing back and forth between each port.Yhere are many different types of ship but you need to work to earn the money,rank and reputatiom to buy new bigger and better ships.Just remember everybody starts a buisnes small and grows over time.
Wow, this is like ports of call. I love this game, it's more casual then a simulator. Economics and ships. Like i said. i loved the old POC, so i like this one!

Good concept but repetative execution. Could be run on a mobile phone, no competition (not that it would matter) and really just repetative.  You will do the same series of clicks for hours on end. Sad since it had potential.

Meh... this game kinda sucks. Buy ships, ship stuff.. make money to buy more ships to ship more stuff. There's a mini game throughout that lets you dock or depart from harbors but it gets super tedious and you'll just dock with tug boats in the end otherwise this game would last forever.   You can get contracts which give you a certain amount of money when you finish them, but it's usually a hasle to re-route all your ships to these docks. Plus sometimes these docks are too small for your ships so onlly your smaller ♥♥♥♥♥ier ships can go which get f'ing annoying and take forever.   Then there are the big contracts whenever you rank up, you'll get 2 or 3 and you can fail them and it doesn't matter. Then on the 3rd or 4th you'll get a mandatory one. If you don't fulfill that one it's game over which I was getting bored with this game and I didn't read this fact. So game over... I don't understand this mechanic... It should of been quite clear with a secondary warning if this kind of thing is implemented.   I won't be going back to this game, nor will I be recommending it to anyone. It's really basic, The mini game of docking is not fun and is very repetitive.    I got 15 hrs out of it... good enough I guess but I was expecting more depth to this game.
Perfect game
This game reminds me of Tropico, I can wait for no. 2. It gets boring playing single player but Its very fun and casual.

Pretty craptastic.  Not many ships to choose from. No real customization.  Gameplay consists of navigating your ship in and out of port. Once you're out of the port, it is automated until you get to the next port. Then you get to navigate out of port again. Whee.  You get to select a contract to take, but it really isn't very involved at all. Will it fit on your ship, and can you make it to the port in time? If so, take it. Otherwise, don't.  That's the game. Wish there was more to tell you.

I agree this style of game isn't for everyone. That being said I personally enjoy it very much. The gameplay is consistent, graphics are nice even though they're simple. I have not had any crashes, glitches or bugs of any kind.

I was introdused to the game by squirrel. I love the game, but it is unfortunately not the type of game for me. I will recommend this game for anyone interested in these kinds of games. Somethings i would have liked to see in the future is to add more mini games, preferably in the wildcards. Maneuvering thru a storm, or rescue passengers for reduced times or a small benefit for the player.
Sail them sea to deliver!

I like Tycoon games a lot, they're my single favourite genre, so when I saw a game allowing me to be a shipping magnate I was pretty interested. Reviews were mixed but it was on sale for only a few pounds so I took a gamble.  To keep this short, the game is relatively fun but quickly becomes repetitive and my patience has worn thin long before completing a single play through of the campaign mode. You start the game, buy a ship at your home port and select one of the available contracts to ship goods across the globe. You watch a little graphic of your ship go from port to port and when you dock at the other end you earn your money (or not as the case may be), sound fun? Well I hope so because you're going to do that thousands and thousands of times. You buy more ships and bigger ships and upgrade ships to carry different cargo but it all boils down to selecting contracts, sending your ship to sea and watching the moeny roll in.  I've sunk enough hours in to this that I've got my moneys worth (less than a pound per hours gameplay at time of writing) and whilst I certainly don't feel ripped off I wouldn't recommend this game to anyone but the most die hard management/tycoon fan.  Overall not bad but not interesting either.

Ports of Call was released in 1987, almost 30 years ago. This game is a copycat of it. It is way worse than the original.   Big problem: No multiplayer on the same computer. So you cannot play together with your friends. On the other hand, this might not be so big of a problem, as this game is extremely monotone and gets hectic, but not fun, when your fleet exceeds a handful of ships. So who would play it for longer sessions anyways.  I would definitely stay away and get the old game, if you like such games.
very nice bussiness sim game!it has great graphics and the gameplay is a bit repeatative but its addictive..smuggling is fun ^^

EDIT: Im STUPID, I didnt check if this was a multiplayer game or not and its NOT.  If they update the game and make it a multiplayer game i will recomend it.  For all of us oldies that remember Ports of Call, this game is Ports of Call with some minor tweeks. I havent tried free game, but from what iv seen so far (16h) i dont expect it to be that far from PoC.
I have been waiting a long time for a shipping game like this.There is a few things that could be better (tug fees are to high) but all in all a good laid back game.
love it <3
Really fun and simple game, as a Ship enthusiast it was a nice find. However the game could add more ship types like bulk carriers and oil tankers, they would fit really well with the game.

7/10  This game does what it's meant to do well. However, it is not at all what I expected. It plays exactly like 'Plague Inc.' with boats instead of a virus.  I guess I assumed this would kind of play like Euro Truck Sim 2 with boats...IT'S NOT AT ALL.  Having said all that:  I was initially disappointed with the game because I thought I was getting something else, but it plays so well that I think I'll stick around a bit...
It won't run with EVGA precision in the background. Yay! Seem to be having a lot of problems with stuff like that. Anywho, good game yes.
how to get company contract in transocean pc game

- Abandoned by the developer, which moved on to make the sequel.  - Poor fleet management, when u get up in ship numbers. (No automatic route option, alot of clicking) - Not hard, and not really deep gameplay - Lacking in replayability. (No game settings to make it harder, no computer competition)  + Fun for awhile + Basics of the game is done well. (if they build on it for the 2nd one, it should be a decent title)  If you want a time waster, and liked ports of call, you might like this.  I wouldn't pick it up, unless it was on a discount though.
I enjoyed it great gameplay

How to review this game... I like it, it's a good fleet management/trading game but it's really not for everybody.  The manual docking is kinda fun at first and saves money but with a fleet of a 100 ships it gets tedious so as soon as you have the cash you'll start auto-docking. The investor's fees are crippling and not that easy to plan for, since you don't know exactly how high it will be.  You'll spend most of your time picking the most profitable contract(s) trying to keep your boats full of high value cargo and going nuts trying to complete the crazy company contracts that the investor chooses for you.  Still I've completed the game twice and will probably do it again.

Ports of Call feeling - Hell Yes!  But after just a few hours the game is getting boring way too fast! Its only a visual/graphic update to Ports of Call with no added content or even a competitive gameplay. You can make money way to fast end easy, means you can buy more ships and make even more money. I play on highest difficulty and the game doesnt really pushes me. No story or real campaigns.  After all I am very dissapointed by the game, just a cheap copy of Ports of Call. Price is way to high for what you get and can do ingame!  Sorry was really looking and hoping for more

I started the game and time slept by in seconds. After a while, I really felt my responcibility before my contractors. Damn I hate sudden cargo chacks. Sure this game has problems in mechanics and it really needs polishing, but I like half-life games, it makes me happy. Perfect games are sometimes boring.
